item.title: Creating an adjustment
item.description: Many of the widgets which use adjustment objects do so automatically, but some cases will be shown in later examples where you may need to create one yourself. You create an adjustment using GData.adjustment: val GData.adjustment : ?value:float -> ?lower:float -> ?upper:float -> ?step_incr:float -> ?page_incr:float -> ?page_size:float -> unit -> adjustment lower : default value is 0. upper : default value is 100. step_incr : default value is 1. page_incr : default value is 10.

item.title: Using adjustments
item.description: The adjustable widgets can be roughly divided into those which use and require specific units for these values and those which treat them as arbitrary numbers. The group which treats the values as arbitrary numbers includes the range widgets (scrollbars and scales, the progress bar widget, and the spin button widget). These widgets are all the widgets which are typically “adjusted” directly by the user with the mouse or keyboard. They will treat the lower and upper values of an adjustment as a range within which the user can manipulate the adjustment’s value.
